history.content:
I don't know if you can skip math 54 (doubt it), but might as well take ee47d to learn circuit stuff before ee16b if you're confident in your math 54 skills.

___________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

You can definitely take Math 110 directly as long as you know how to write mathematical proofs (Math 55 level). It starts linear algebra from the basics. As someone who took both classes, I would say it doesn't really require any 54 knowledge at all (the textbook is just a standard undergrad linear algebra book that covers more than the 54 book but without a diff eq section) It just presents the material in a more abstract way and with more proofs than in 54; starts with vector spaces instead of systems of linear equations. Same material but different ordering.

I don't know if you can skip math 54 (doubt it), but might as well take ee47d to learn circuit stuff before ee16b if you're confident in your math 54 skills.

___________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Same stuff, just different ordering.

I don't know if you can skip math 54 (doubt it), but might as well take ee47d to learn circuit stuff before ee16b if you're confident in your math 54 skills.

You can definitely take Math 110 directly as long as you know how to write mathematical proofs (Math 55 level). It starts linear algebra from the basics. As someone who took both classes, I would say it doesn't really require any 54 knowledge at all (the textbook is just a standard college linear algebra book that covers more than the 54 book but without a diff eq section) It just presents the material in a more abstract way and with more proofs than in 54; starts with vector spaces instead of systems of linear equations. Same stuff, just different ordering.

I don't know if you can skip math 54 (doubt it), but might as well take ee47d to learn circuit stuff before ee16b if you're confident in your math 54 skills.

children.subject:
That’s still very amazing for finishing five techs a semester (4 math upperdivs+16b)!
May I ask you how you feel about that? How did you maintained your GPA along this way?
Wait what how are you finishing all the math upper divs by your second semester of freshman year??????????? Is that even possible

history.content:
I am a LS freshman and applied math + CS intended. I'm declaring double major next semester. However, the official lower division requirements for CS major has only two options: math 54 + ee 16b and ee 16a + ee 16b. I wonder if math 110 + ee 16b is also an option, given that I declare double major?

I have already completed math 110 this semester (taking ee16b next semester). I plan to talk to a math major advisor early next semester to get head advisor's approval of skipping math 53 and 54 in math department requirements (since I will finish all the upper division required math courses next semester). Does the signature from head advisor in math department (or consent from math department of skipping math 54) work to override the math 54/ee 16a requirement in CS major? Or should I ask Prof. Sahai for an exception?

(Requesting answer from instructors)
history.subject: Math 110 + EE 16B for lower division requirement?
